Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and I’m sitting at my kitchen table, laptop open, spreadsheets glowing on the screen. My phone buzzes—a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock. I haven’t called home in over a week, and guilt pricks at me. I know they worry if I don’t check in, and I promised I’d be better about staying in touch. But just as I start to type a reply, my work email pings. A client is confused about a line item on their invoice and wants an immediate explanation. I know I should respond quickly; it’s part of my job to be available and clear, even on weekends. My mind races, torn between the warmth of my parents’ expectations and the professional responsibility pressing on me. I stare at my phone, then at my laptop, feeling the weight of both worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
